key_points: Forensic car accident experts suggest Tiger Woods may have been asleep or not paying attention before his crash.
Evidence indicates Woods did not lose control due to excessive speed but rather inattention.
No skid marks were found; vehicle's anti-lock brakes may explain the absence.
Woods' vehicle traveled straight on a curved road, went off the road, hit a tree, and rolled over, causing major damage and breaking Woods' lower right leg.
Experts theorize a late brake application, suggesting Woods was possibly unconscious or asleep until off-road.
Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva and others labeled the crash an accident, though impairment has been ruled out.
Forensic experts question the quick determination without analyzing vehicle's black box or Woods' medical data for medication.
In 2017, Woods was found asleep at the wheel with several substances in his system, raising questions about possible medication at the time of the crash.
Experts criticize the initial assessment of the crash as an accident, suggesting negligence might be involved.
Woods is recovering from surgery and is in good spirits, with no further updates on his condition.
spokespersons: Jonathan Cherney (Consultant, car accident analysis expert witness)
Felix Lee (Accident reconstruction expert, Expert Institute)
